Newly released CCTV footage shows floodwater raging through a library in Long Island, New York, causing about $10m (£7.5m) in damage.

The flood - on 19 August - was caused by heavy rainfall, and knocked down walls, swept away objects and destroyed centuries-old books and documents.

At the time, Suffolk County - where the library is located - and New York State declared a state of emergency, opening the door for federal assistance to help the rebuild effort.

In a post on its website, the library said the building will remain closed 'until further notice... while we continue to assess the damage and begin to rebuild'.

2.text:

The flood occurred on August 19, when a severe storm battered the area, knocking down walls, sweeping away items, and in the process, destroying hundreds of years of historical documents and files.

At the time, Suffolk County, where the library is located, as well as the state of New York, declared a state of emergency and opened the door to federal aid to help with the rebuilding efforts.

In a post on its website, the library stated that it would 'remain closed until we continue to assess the damage and begin the rebuilding process.'

The latest CCTV footage comes from the Long Island Library in New York State, showing that the library suffered approximately $1 billion in flood damage (approximately £750 million).

The flood occurred on August 19, when strong winds swept through the area, causing walls to collapse, items to be washed away, and ultimately destroying centuries-old historical documents and archives.

At the time, Suffolk County and New York State both declared a state of emergency, activating federal aid to assist with the rebuilding efforts.

According to an article on the library's official website, the library will be closed before the loss assessment and rebuilding work begins.

Note that the exchange rate between pounds (£) and dollars ($) may fluctuate, so the described losses may vary depending on the change in exchange rates.

Former health minister and Conservative MP Daniel Poulter has defected to Labour, saying he disagreed with the Conservative Party's handling of the NHS.

In an exclusive TV interview with BBC's Laura Kuenssberg, the Central Suffolk and North Ipswich MP said the NHS 'deserves better'.

He said: 'I found it increasingly difficult to look my NHS colleagues in the eye, my patients in the eye, and my constituents in the eye with good conscience.'

Dr Poulter, who was first elected in 2010, served as a health minister for several years under the coalition.

You can watch his full interview on Sunday with Laura Kuenssberg, BBC One at 09:00 BST.

Two women die and one man critical after crash

The crash happed on the A4050 in Barry, Vale of Glamorgan, near Pugh’s Garden Centre

Two women have died and two men have been taken to hospital, one in a critical condition, after a crash. It happened on the A4050 in Barry, Vale of Glamorgan, at about 13:40 GMT on Saturday, and the road closed from the junction of Port Road East and Barry Dock Link Road to Pugh’s Garden Centre. South Wales Police said two women died at the scene and two men are currently receiving treatment in hospital.

Sgt Craig Wood said: “First and foremost, our thoughts are with the family of the two women who have died in this collision. “We are in the early stages of our investigation and are still trying to establish the full circumstances.' He appealed for anyone driving in the area between 13:30 and 13:50 on Saturday who may have information to get in touch. 'We are particularly keen to hear from anyone who can give us extra detail on the manner of driving of a grey Audi RS 4 prior to the collision,' he added.

0.text:
Tommie-lee Gracie Billington was found at a house on Greenset Close in Lancaster

The family of an 11-year-old boy who died after apparently taking part in a dangerous social media craze say they are 'devastated'.

Tommie-lee Gracie Billington died at a house in Greenset Close in Lancaster, Lancashire, on Saturday.

His grandmother Tina Burns said he had been at a sleepover taking part in a social media craze that involves sniffing or inhaling toxic fumes.

In a tribute to the schoolboy, she said she had 'never felt pain like this'.

Writing on Facebook, she added: 'I will make sure to the best of my ability that your name and your beautiful face will become the reason that other children's lives will be saved and other families don't have to suffer this deep, deep hurt.'

Police said the boy's death was being treated as unexplained and whether he had inhaled aerosols was one line of inquiry.

The force said previously the coroner had been informed.

Why not follow BBC Lancashire on Facebook, X and Instagram? You can also send story ideas to northwest.newsonline@bbc.co.uk

0.text:
'Labour's secret tax rise dossier' and 'financial turmoil at IT giant'

This picture of Prime Minister Rishi Sunak on a boat made on to several front pages

Sir Ian McKellen is in 'good spirits' after falling off stage during a performance of Player Kings, a spokesperson said

Sir Ian McKellen's recovery after a fall off the stage earlier this week is featured in many of the papers. The 85-year-old lost his footing while performing in a fight scene during a performance of Player Kings in London. He's expected to return to the show tomorrow, with the Times, external, the Guardian, external and the Daily Mail, external all using variations of the phrase 'the show must go on' in their headlines. And the Sun says half of the Premier League trophy has been replaced, external after it was stolen. The paper says thieves in Belgium took a case containing the base and crown in late 2022, and it's believed the missing parts may have been melted down.

Sign up for our morning newsletter and get BBC News in your inbox.

0.text:
The NFL has issued a security warning to players about a criminal network targeting their homes.

Players have been urged to ramp up security and take care about what they post on social media.

It comes after the homes of Kansas City Chiefs stars Patrick Mahomes and Travis Kelce were burgled last month, while a property owned by Dallas Cowboys' Linval Joseph was targeted last week.

An NFL security memo about the issue has been sent out to team security directors and the players' union.

Reporting on the memo, the NFL website said it was understood the criminal organisation 'use public records to find players' addresses and conduct extensive surveillance'.

'Then, by tracking team schedules and the social media accounts of players and their families, they wait until homes are empty - often during games.'

Players have also been asked to make it look like someone is at home when they are out, by leaving lights or a television on, for example.

'I can't get into too many of the details because the investigation is still ongoing,' Mahomes said when asked about the break in.

'But obviously something that you don't want to happen to really anybody, but obviously yourself.'

2.text:
The NFL issued a security alert, warning players that organized crime groups are targeting their families.

Players are being asked to increase security measures and exercise caution when posting content on social media.

This comes after the homes of Kansas City Chiefs players Patrick Mahomes and Travis Kelce were broken into last month, and after the property of Dallas Cowboys player Trevon Diggs was attacked.

The NFL's security memo has been sent to team security directors and union officials.

According to a report on the NFL website, the memo states that organized crime groups are using public records to find players' addresses and track them.

'They then track the team's schedule, players' and their families' social media accounts, waiting for family members to leave, usually during games.'

Players are also being asked to make it appear as though someone is at home when they leave, such as by turning on lights or the TV.

'I can't reveal too many details because the investigation is ongoing,' Mahomes said when asked about the break-ins. 'But this is clearly something you don't want to happen, especially to yourself.'

Recent incidents involving Kansas City Chiefs quarterback Patrick Mahomes and safety Travis Kelce, as well as Dallas Cowboys defensive player Micah Parsons, have seen organized crime groups targeting their families and properties, totaling tens of thousands of dollars.

The NFL's safety alert has been sent to team security personnel and union officials.

According to the NFL's official website, the alert states that organized crime groups are using publicly available records to locate players' addresses and track them.

The alert reads: 'They will wait for family members to leave, usually when the player's schedule and the team's schedule overlap, based on the team's schedule, the player and their family will post information on their social media accounts.'

Players are also being asked to make it appear as though someone is home when leaving, such as turning on lights or the TV.

Mahomes said: 'Given the ongoing investigation, I can't say too much. 'This is not something you want to happen, especially when it happens to you.''

Holders Rangers will visit Celtic in the SWPL Cup semi-finals, with Hibernian facing visitors Aberdeen in the other last-four tie.

CCTV footage has captured brazen shoplifters and smash-and-grab raiders targeting stores on Edinburgh's Royal Mile.

Shopkeepers say the area has become 'lawless' with thousands of pounds' worth of goods stolen in recent months.

BBC News has obtained CCTV showing people walking out of shops with expensive cashmere scarves, jumpers and jackets in broad daylight.

One man can be seen kicking in a plate-glass window at night to steal armfuls of Harris Tweed bags, costing up to £150 each.

Staff say the area has become dangerous and intimidating, and that despite reporting thefts to police on an almost daily basis, nothing has been done.

Police Scotland says a dedicated team is working with businesses in the area and is investigating every report.

Oxford Street has switched on its annual Christmas lights display, becoming the first of the major London illuminations to be turned on for 2024.

More than 300,000 LED stars once again make up the lights, making them about 75% more energy efficient than standard lights.

It starts a season of events on Oxford Street including a partnership with Great Ormond Street Hospital's GOSH Charity.

Business groups hope the lights will provide a boost to retailers too as they gear up for the Christmas trade over the next seven weeks.

Last updated on .From the section Football

Southampton have postponed Wednesday's Championship fixture with Preston North End following a major fire next to their St Mary's ground.

The club took the decision after consultation with local authorities and emergency services, with widespread disruption caused by the blaze.

Roads around the stadium are closed as fire crews continue to deal with the situation.

A new date for the rescheduled fixture will be announced in due course.

The blaze is in the industrial units on Marine Parade just yards from the ground.

Wednesday's postponed game was one of five matches scheduled for the Championship.

Russell Martin's Saints side are fourth in the table, eight points behind second-placed Ipswich, but with an 11-point buffer on West Bromwich Albion below them in fifth.

Preston are ninth and four points outside the play-off places.

'We are grateful for the cooperation of Preston and the EFL, and while we appreciate the disappointment fans may feel, we hope they will understand the need to put the safety of supporters and staff of both clubs first,' a Southampton statement said.

The club consulted with local authorities and emergency services before deciding to postpone the match, due to the widespread disruption caused by the fire.

The roads around the stadium have been closed and the fire service is still dealing with the situation.

A new date for the rearranged match will be announced later.

The fire occurred at an industrial unit near the seafront promenade, just a short distance from the stadium.

The postponed match is one of five Championship matches affected by the situation.

Martin's Saints are currently fourth in the table, eight points behind second-placed Ipswich but 11 points ahead of fifth-placed West Bromwich.

Preston are ninth in the table, four points behind fourth-placed teams (who qualify for the playoffs).

A statement from Southampton FC said: 'We would like to thank Preston and the EFL for their cooperation, although we understand that fans may be disappointed, we hope they can understand the necessity of putting the safety of fans and club staff first.'

0.text:
The SNP leadership campaign got personal today.

But it's the Scottish Tory leader Douglas Ross who fired the first shots at both leading candidates - and the SNP.

During the debate on the no confidence vote on the Scottish government, he said it looks like Nicola Sturgeon's Health Secretary (Humza Yousaf) will be replaced by her deputy (that's John Swinney) or her finance secretary (Kate Forbes).

Ms Forbes, he claimed, had raised taxes for Scottish workers and was “an even more radical nationalist' than Humza Yousaf or Nicola Sturgeon.

So far, so knockabout - prompting a bemused smile from Ms Forbes.

But then, the focus switched to Mr Swinney - or 'Honest John' as Douglas Ross called him - and then 'Not So Honest John'.

This earned a rebuke from the presiding officer - and Douglas Ross was forced to apologise.

Amid roars from fellow MSPs, John Swinney looked livid - wagging his finger at Douglas Ross - and voicing his anger.

But the first blows have been landed. And both leading candidates have been put on notice about what may lie ahead if they become first minister.

2.text:
The leadership contest for the SNP has become increasingly personalized.

However, in the debate over opposing the Scottish government's vote of confidence, Scottish Conservative leader Douglas Ross launched a preemptive attack on the two SNP leadership contenders.

He claimed that Health Secretary Humza Yousaf, Nicola Sturgeon's likely successor, would be replaced by her deputy John Swinney or Finance Secretary Kate Forbes.

Ms Forbes, he said, had previously raised taxes for Scottish workers and was 'more nationalist' than Humza Yousaf or Nicola Sturgeon.

This remark left Ms Forbes looking dejected.

But things were only going to get worse, as the focus shifted to Mr Swinney, or 'honest John' versus 'dishonest John'.

This prompted a warning from the host - Douglas Ross was forced to apologize.

As his colleagues applauded, John Swinney's face turned red with anger, pointing at Douglas Ross to express his rage.

But the first attack had already been made. Both leadership contenders received a warning - what would happen if they became First Minister?

4.text:
In the SNP leadership election, the selection process has gradually become personalized.

However, in the debate on the Scottish government's confidence vote, Scottish Conservative leader Douglas Ross launched a pre-emptive attack on the SNP leadership election candidates.

He claimed that Health Secretary Humza Yousaf, who is likely to succeed Nicola Sturgeon as Scotland's First Lady, would be replaced by Nicola Sturgeon's deputy John Swinney or Finance Secretary Kate Forbes.

He said that Ms Forbes had previously raised taxes for Scottish workers and believed she was more nationalist than Humza Yousaf or Nicola Sturgeon.

This comment left Ms Forbes looking dejected.

But things were about to get worse, as the focus shifted to John Swinney, or rather 'Honest John' versus 'Unhonest John'.

This prompted the host to issue a warning, forcing Douglas Ross to apologize.

As his colleagues applauded, John Swinney's face turned red, and he pointed at Douglas Ross, expressing his anger.

But the first wave of attacks had already begun. All the leadership candidates received a warning – what would happen if they became Scotland's First Lady?

0.text:
The oldest person in Wales has celebrated her 112th birthday.

Mary Keir was surrounded by friends and family for a roast lunch followed by sherry trifle and then a buffet in the evening.

She spent the big day at Awel Tywi Residential Home in Llandeilo, Carmarthenshire, where she has lived for 12 years.

Mrs Keir is actively involved in life at the home, where she takes part in activities, entertainment and meetings.

Carmarthenshire council said she was also a keen lover of music, in particular the piano which had been a lifelong passion.

Mrs Keir worked as a ward sister and district nurse and lived in Llansteffan independently until just before her 100th birthday.

'Mary, our mother and mother-in-law still has a great will and determination,' her son Robert Keir and daughter-in law Sian Keir said in a statement.

'She has received fantastic care at Awel Tywi and we really appreciate everything that the amazing staff do for her every day,' they added.

Pupils from Ysgol Ffairfach, as well as Dinefwr Male Voice Choir, also visited the care home to celebrate.

Nottingham Forest owner Evangelos Marinakis' appeal against a five-game stadium ban was dismissed to 'send a clear message' after he 'undermined respect for the game of football,' says the Football Association (FA).

The 57-year-old was found guilty of improper conduct for spitting on the floor as the match officials walked past following Forest's 1-0 Premier League defeat by Fulham at the City Ground on 28 September.

Marinakis denied the charge and appealed against the Regulatory Commission’s outcome, before it was later dismissed by an Appeal Board.

In a statement adding clarity to the appeal rejection, the FA said: 'Showing such contempt for match officials in a place where that can be seen by other individuals, significantly undermines respect for the game of football.

'Such behaviour is only more serious when it comes from an individual who himself has a position of both power and responsibility within the game.

'It is therefore vital that a clear message is sent that this behaviour will not be tolerated in any part of football.'

A London doctor is nearing the end of an intense training regime as he prepares to take on seven ironman triathlons in seven days for charity.

Dr Rob Mitchell, 32, who is from Hampshire but now lives in Tooting, south London, is raising money for men's health charity Movember, and the DMRC Benevolent Fund, which helps injured servicemen and women.

An ironman triathlon consists of a 2.4 miles (3.8km) swim, a 112 miles (180.2km) bicycle ride and a 26.2 miles (42km) marathon, with Dr Mitchell hoping to complete seven of them over seven consecutive days, starting on 18 August.

Manchester United defender Luke Shaw has returned to training following three months out with injury.

The England left-back, who has not played for the club since February, sustained a calf injury in early August.

He had been expected to return after the international break in October but former manager Erik ten Hag said Shaw had suffered a 'setback'.

Shaw injured his hamstring in February which ruled him out of the remainder of the last Premier League season.

However, he was selected in England's squad for Euro 2024 and started the final defeat by Spain after missing the group phase.

United welcomed back Christian Eriksen and Mason Mount from injury during the side's 2-0 Europa League win against PAOK on Thursday.

Leny Yoro, a summer signing from Lille, is yet to make his competitive debut for the club after fracturing his foot in pre-season but is now back in training.

Interim manager Ruud van Nistelrooy says the club's injury problems are starting to ease.

'Christian played 30 minutes and Mason also played,' said Van Nistelrooy.

'It's beneficial for us and I'm happy that they're back. For the long-term absentees like Luke and Leny they are on the pitch with us.'

2.text:
Luke Shaw, Manchester United's defender, has returned to training and ended his three-month layoff due to injury.

Since February, England's left-back Shaw has been unable to play for the team due to injury, and in early August, he was unable to participate in any matches due to a tendon sheath injury.

Initially, Shaw was expected to return to the team after the international break in October, but former manager Erik ten Hag said Shaw had 'regressed'.

In February, Shaw was again unable to participate in the remaining league matches due to a hamstring injury.

However, he was still selected to join the England team for the 2024 European Cup and made a substitute appearance in the final against Spain, with England ultimately losing 0-2 to Spain.

0.text:
Knightsbridge is famous for its high-end shopping

A man has been charged with kidnapping and sexually assaulting a nine-year-old girl who was reported missing in Knightsbridge.

Robert Prussak, 56, appeared at Westminster Magistrates' Court earlier and was remanded in custody.

The girl was reported missing from Brompton Road, west London, at 14:44 BST on Monday and was found by officers at 17:40 in Old Court Place.

She and her family are being supported by police, detectives said.

Mr Prussak, of no fixed address, is also also charged with administering a substance with the intention of stupefying or overpowering to enable sexual activity.

He is due to appear at Isleworth Crown Court on 22 May.

CCTV footage has been released showing the moment a stolen milk float crashed into a wall.

Rico Siddell and Luke Solomon assaulted the milkman while he was on his rounds in Basford, Nottingham, on 17 March 2022.

He was punched repeatedly to the head by both offenders and briefly lost consciousness.

Police later found the vehicle embedded in a wall in Tewkesbury Drive, with smoke coming from the bonnet and a pool of milk all over the street.

Both defendants were sentenced to two years in a young offenders institution, suspended for 21 months.

0.text:
One dead and five injured in York bus crash - police

Two air ambulances landed at the scene

One person has died and five others have been injured following a crash between a double decker bus and a car in York. Emergency services were called to Wetherby Road, near Rufforth, at 09:22 BST on Saturday. North Yorkshire Police said a 31-year-old man - a passenger in a Tesla - had died at the scene. The driver, a 32-year-old man, was taken to hospital with serious injuries. Three other passengers in the Tesla, along with driver of the bus, were treated for minor injuries.

The road was closed until 17:30 BST, police said

Two air ambulances joined three other ambulances and a Hazardous Area Response Team, as well as police, to deal with the incident. According to police, the deceased man is from the Newcastle area. The Tesla driver is from Teesside, the force added. The road was reopened at 17:25 BST. Anyone with information about the crash, or who has dashcam footage, is asked to contact police. Follow BBC Yorkshire on Facebook, external, X (formerly Twitter), external and Instagram, external. Send your story ideas to yorkslincs.news@bbc.co.uk, external

Two rescue helicopters landed at the scene of the accident.

A double-decker bus collided with a car in York, injuring five passengers. Police said that at 09:22 BST on Saturday morning, emergency services received a 999 call from Wetherby Road (near Rufforth). North Yorkshire Police said a 31-year-old man, who was in a Tesla, died at the scene of the accident. The driver, a 32-year-old man, was taken to hospital for treatment. Three other Tesla passengers and the bus driver suffered minor injuries.

Police said the road was closed at 17:30 BST.

Two rescue helicopters joined three ambulances, a hazardous area response team and police in dealing with the accident. According to police, the deceased man was from the New Castle area. 0.text:
Nottingham Forest captain Morgan Gibbs-White, manager Nuno Espirito Santo and Brighton boss Fabian Hurzeler have been charged by the Football Association following their red cards in Sunday's Premier League match.

Gibbs-White was dismissed in the 83rd minute after receiving a second booking, with the two managers sent off in the aftermath.

The Forest midfielder has been charged with acting in an improper manner and/or using abusive and/or insulting words towards fourth official Anthony Taylor.

Both Nuno and Hurzeler are charged with acting in an improper manner, with the Portuguese also alleged to have used abusive and/or insulting words towards a match official.

The trio have until Friday, 27 September to respond.

Gibbs-White was shown a second yellow card for a sliding challenge on Brighton's Joao Pedro with seven minutes remaining.

Hurzeler and Nuno, were dismissed by referee Rob Jones for their reactions to the incident on the touchline towards the end of the entertaining 2-2 draw, in which both clubs maintained their unbeaten Premier League starts.

Gibbs-White and Nuno will be missing for Forest's home league game against Fulham on Saturday, while Hurzeler will not be in the dugout when Brighton travel to Chelsea the same day (both 15:00 BST).

2.text:
Nottingham Forest captain Morgan Gibbs-White, captain Nuno Espirito Santo and Brighton captain Fabian Hurzeler are facing a Football Association (FA) charge for their red cards in the Premier League match on Sunday.

Gibbs-White was sent off in the 83rd minute after receiving his second yellow card, and the two captains were subsequently red-carded shortly after.

Gibbs-White was sent off for a late challenge on Brighton's Joao Pedro in the 80th minute, which earned him his second yellow card. Nuno and Hurzeler were red-carded by referee Rob Jones at the end of the match.

Despite the red cards, the two teams maintained their unbeaten Premier League records as the match ended 2-2.

Gibbs-White and Nuno will miss their teams' respective matches due to their red cards: Gibbs-White for Nottingham Forest against Fulham at home, and Nuno for Brighton against Chelsea.

They must respond to the charges by September 27. Gibbs-White is charged with misconduct and/or using abusive and/or insulting language towards fourth official Anthony Taylor after receiving his second yellow card.

Nuno and Hurzeler are also charged with misconduct, and Nuno is further charged with using abusive and/or insulting language towards match officials.

4.text:
Morgan Gibbs-White, the captain of Nottingham Forest, and Fabian Hurzeler, the captain of Brighton, along with Brighton coach Nuno Espirito Santo, are facing disciplinary action from the English Football Association (FA) after being sent off in last Sunday's Premier League match.

Gibbs-White was sent off in the 83rd minute after receiving his second yellow card for chasing Brighton's Joao Pedro in the evening. Both captains were subsequently red-carded. Gibbs-White received his second yellow card in the 80th minute for his late chase of Pedro. Nuno and Hurzeler were sent off by referee Rob Jones at the end of the match.

Despite both teams' captains being sent off, they maintained their unbeaten record in the Premier League, with the match ending 2-2.

Gibbs-White and Nuno will miss their respective teams' matches due to their red cards: Gibbs-White will miss Nottingham Forest's home match against Fulham, while Nuno will miss Brighton's match against Chelsea. They must respond to the disciplinary action by September 27.

Gibbs-White is charged with misconduct for using abusive language towards fourth official Anthony Taylor when he received his second yellow card. Nuno and Hurzeler are also charged with misconduct, with Nuno additionally charged with using abusive language towards the referee during the match.

6.text:

Gibbs-White is charged with misconduct for using abusive language towards fourth official Anthony Taylor when he received his second yellow card. Nuno and Hurzeler are also charged with misconduct, with Nuno also charged with using abusive language to accuse the referee during the match.

Officers made the vehicle pull over before escorting the couple to safety

An elderly couple who got lost in Manchester ended up driving around the city for 10 hours.

Police came to the aid of the pair, who had driven to Manchester from Wales and had been reported as lost.

They were spotted on the M60 and eventually stopped on the M62, with the driver said to be 'confused'.

Tweeting about the incident, Greater Manchester Police said it had given the pair a 'blue-light, first-class taxi back to safety'.

A shoplifting bird dubbed 'Steven Seagull' has been banned from a convenience store for flying off with packets of crisps over a six-year stealing spree.

Staff at the Lyndale Central store in Wyke Regis, Dorset, have put up posters urging customers to 'close the door' behind them in a bid to stop Steven.

The manager of the store, Stuart Harmer, said the crafty seagull had made off with about 30 packets of crisps in the past two months alone.

He said: 'Trying to explain to the powers that be that I've got stock loss because of a seagull - they think its a joke.'

Store manager Stuart Harmer said that the cunning seagull had stolen around 30 packets of snacks over the past two months. He said, 'I have tried to explain to the authorities the losses I have incurred due to the seagull - they think it's a joke.'

Video from Russian television shows Americans Evan Gershkovich and Paul Whelan board a plane after their release as part of a prisoner exchange between Russia and the West.

Sixteen prisoners have been released from Russian prisons in the biggest exchange deal since the Cold War.

Gershkovich, a Wall Street Journal reporter, and Whelan, a US Marine veteran who also holds Canadian, British and Irish citizenship, are among those on their way back to the US.

Footage also shows Russian prisoners that were swapped in the exchange returning to Russia.

US President Joe Biden has celebrated the release of American prisoners, adding that the exchange was largely due to American allies.

Emergency services were called to Burnt Oak Broadway on Thursday morning

A man has appeared in court charged with the murder of a woman who was stabbed near a bus stop in north-west London. The victim, aged 66, was treated by paramedics on Burnt Oak Broadway in Edgware on Thursday but died shortly before midday. Jalal Debella, 22, from Colindale, did not enter a plea at Willesden Magistrates' Court. He is due to appear at the Old Bailey on Tuesday. The Met Police previously said the attack was an 'isolated incident' and no further suspects were being sought. The stabbing happened close to the junction with Limesdale Gardens at about 11:50 BST. The woman's family has been informed.

Jalal Debella, 22, from Colindale, appeared at Willesden Magistrates' Court without comment. He is due to appear at the Old Bailey on Tuesday. The Metropolitan Police had earlier described the attack as an 'isolated incident', indicating that no further suspects would be pursued. On Thursday morning, police issued an emergency alert on Oakwood Road.

Jalal Deghayes, 22, from Colindale, appeared at Highbury Magistrates' Court on Tuesday and at Willesden Magistrates' Court on Wednesday, charged with the murder of a 66-year-old woman in north London.

The victim died shortly after receiving treatment at a bus stop near Oakwood Road.

Initially, the Metropolitan Police described the incident as an 'isolated incident', suggesting that no one else had been arrested. However, at 11:50 am on Thursday, a similar incident occurred in Lindisfarne Gardens.

The victim's family has been informed.

0.text:
Video footage shows the moment a lorry driver crashed in north Wales after being distracted by his mobile phone.

The dashcam and CCTV images show Raymond Catterall, 44, looking down at his phone before swerving the vehicle off the A55 at Tal-y-Bont, Gwynedd, and crashing in adjacent bushes.

He hits a stationary broken down car, as well as almost hitting three people and a dog stood on the grassy verge.

Catterall pleaded guilty to dangerous driving and using a handheld mobile phone whilst driving. He was given an eight-month suspended prison sentence, 150 hours of unpaid work, a three-month curfew and a 12-month driving disqualification at Caernarfon Crown Court.

2.text:
A video clip shows a truck driver in north Wales distracted by his phone, which led to a car accident.

The video and CCTV footage show 44-year-old Raymond Catterall leaving the A55 highway and crashing into a thicket near Tal-y-Bont. He then looked at his phone.

Catterall collided with an old car parked by the roadside, almost at the same time as three people and a dog standing on the grass.

Catterall pleaded guilty to using a handheld phone while driving and driving dangerously. He was sentenced to eight months' suspended prison sentence, 150 hours of unpaid work, a three-month curfew, and a one-year driving ban at Caernarfon Crown Court.

0.text:
XL Bullies are now subject to restrictions in Scotland

An XL bully-type dog has been put down following an incident in North Lanarkshire.

Armed police were dispatched to Broughton Place in Coatbridge on Thursday amid reports the animal was out of control.

No shots were fired, but the dog was put down by a vet after being restrained by officers.

A 30-year-old woman was reported to the procurator fiscal in connection with an offence under the Dangerous Dogs Act.

No-one was injured in the incident, Police Scotland confirmed.

Restrictions on ownership of XL bully-type dogs were brought into force in Scotland last month.

Under the laws, the breeding and sale of the animals are now banned, while those already kept as pets must be muzzled in public places.

The legislation brought Scotland in line with similar measures put in place in England and Wales following concern over a series of fatal attacks.

The BBC is not responsible for the content of external sites.

Greater Manchester Police has recruited the biggest horse in the force’s 50-year history.

Named Trooper after a character in a Charles Dickens novel, the 10-year-old shire horse measures at 18.2 hands from the ground to shoulders.

Trooper has been described as a 'gentle giant', and the force said the horse would also take part in community events such as school visits.

'Everything size-wise even the bridle, rugs, stable has all got to be enlarged, just to accommodate his comfort,' trainer, Alistair Hunstone said.

Minutes before five women, who had been sexually abused by Mohamed Al Fayed, were due to appear on live TV, one of the group was vomiting in the studio toilets.

It would be Jen’s first time speaking about her experiences without the shield of anonymity - and she was terrified.

“I couldn’t eat that morning,” she recalls of the interview with BBC Breakfast at the end of September.

“I wasn’t very well practised at that point at telling my story and finding words. So I had a very physical reaction.”

About a week earlier, all five women's stories had been featured in a BBC documentary, Al Fayed: Predator at Harrods. The programme uncovered decades of abuse perpetrated by the billionaire and former Harrods owner, who died last year at the age of 94.

Roxana Miskelly, 38, from Inverurie, said the idea was sparked on Monday after a huge amount of snow fell throughout the day.

'Our idea has seemingly now started an epidemic of snowball fights breaking out all over the country, so we may not keep the title of Scotland’s Biggest Snowball Fight for long, but without a doubt we’ll be back at it next year, bigger and better!' she added.

CCTV footage shows the moment a car crashed into a café in Turin, Italy.

The incident happened around 9:30am local time, as customers were enjoying their breakfast inside the local coffee shop.

Seven people were taken to hospital with minor injuries, but there are no reports of casualties.

The speedometer on the car at the moment of the crash got stuck on 115km/h (around 71mph), according to local media.

'It could have been a real carnage, at least 10 people could have died,' Simona Carastro, the café owner's daughter told the BBC.

'Now we're just hoping that we'll be able to reopen the café as soon as possible, considering the extensive financial damage.'

Police are still investigating the circumstances of the crash.

Hyperia is to reopen more than two weeks after it was closed

The UK's tallest rollercoaster is to reopen more than two weeks after it was closed following technical checks. Hyperia at Thorpe Park opened to the public on 24 May but stopped running the day after. In a statement on Tuesday, the theme park in Chertsey, Surrey, said: 'She may have needed a momentary pause after the most epic of launch events, but she's back in full flight'. The theme park said the ride will reopen to guests on Wednesday.

Hyperia is 236ft (72m) tall and has a top speed of 81mph (130km/h). The theme park said the closure followed 'standard technical pre-opening procedure checks', but has not given further details.

'One again we want to thank everyone for their understanding and patience,' a Thorpe Park spokesperson said. The theme park had previously told guests that it was unable to commit to reopening Hyperia before 8 June, adding last week that it was not possible to open the ride on that date.

Follow BBC Surrey on Facebook, external, on X, external. Send your story ideas to southeasttoday@bbc.co.uk , external or WhatsApp us on 08081 002250.

65.text:
A woman who was reading a book witnessed a fatal car accident while driving home, and Thames Valley Police are urging witnesses to come forward to testify. However, one woman responded to the call, claiming that she witnessed the accident.

The woman, who wishes to remain anonymous, said she was driving home when she saw a car suddenly enter the road and hit a pedestrian on the A33.

'I was driving home when I saw a car suddenly enter the road and hit a pedestrian on the A33,' she said. 'I felt extremely frightened, so I stopped the car and helped the injured person.'

The woman described the vehicle as a black Volvo Golf and the pedestrian as a man in his 40s.

'I didn't see the car hit the pedestrian, but I saw it hit him from behind,' she said. 'The vehicle was a black Volvo Golf, and the pedestrian was a man in his 40s.'

The woman said she called the police to report the accident and describe what she saw.

'I called the police to report the accident and describe what I saw,' she said. 'I hope they can catch the perpetrator.'

The police are urging witnesses to come forward to testify and provide any information related to the accident.

'We are urging witnesses to come forward to testify and provide any information related to the accident,' said a police spokesperson. 'If you have any information, please contact us.'

The woman who claimed to have witnessed the accident said she was still trying to process what had happened and was shocked.

'I am still trying to process what happened,' she said. 'This is a terrible thing, and I am still trying to process it.'

The police are still investigating the accident and urging anyone with information to come forward to testify.

'We are still investigating the accident and urging anyone with information to come forward to testify,' said a police spokesperson.

The woman who claimed to have witnessed the accident said she hoped the police could catch the perpetrator.

'I hope the police can catch the perpetrator,' she said. 'This is a terrible thing, and I hope they can bring the perpetrator to justice.'

The accident has shocked the local community, and the police are urging anyone with information to come forward to testify.

'We are urging anyone with information to come forward to testify,' said a police spokesperson. 'If you have any information, please contact us.'

BBC South is following this story and will provide updates as more information becomes available.

For the latest news from BBC South, follow BBC Sussex and BBC South East on Facebook or Twitter, or send your stories and ideas to southeasttoday@bbc.co.uk, or send a WhatsApp message to 08081 002250.

0.text:
Thanks for joining us on our whistle-stop tour of new year celebrations around the world.

We've covered the major displays from Auckland in New Zealand, and the 12-minute extravaganzas in Sydney and Hong Kong.

Hundreds of thousands of people in Paris converged on the Champs-Élysées for an Olympic-themed party ahead of the 2024 Games in July. Central London hosted a firework display, which the organisers said was the biggest in Europe.

Vast crowds gathered at Copacabana beach in the Brazilian city of Rio de Janeiro to welcome in the new year. It's one of the world's biggest celebrations, attracting an estimated two million people.

And in Times Square in New York City, many thousands of revellers witnessed the famous ball drop to mark the moment.

You can dip into more coverage of the new year by reading our news story here

This page was brought to you by Aoife Walsh, Francesca Gillett, Emma Owen, Malu Cursino, James FitzGerald, Sam Horti and me.

Happy new year, one and all!

We've already showcased the highlights of Auckland, New Zealand, as well as the 12-minute spectacle in Sydney and Hong Kong.

In Paris, tens of thousands gathered on the Champs-Élysées to host a party themed around the 2024 Olympics. London's city center hosted a fireworks display, which organizers called the largest in Europe.

On Copacabana Beach in Rio de Janeiro, millions gathered to celebrate the New Year, making it the world's largest celebration, attracting around 2 billion people.

On New York City's Times Square, thousands witnessed the iconic ball drop, marking the moment.

You can click here to read more about New Year's celebrations.

This page was provided by Ophélie Walsh, Francesca Gilet, Emma Owen, Marou Corry, James FitzGerald, Sam Hott and me.

Happy New Year!

50.text:
We would like to extend our heartfelt gratitude to the people around the world who join us in celebrating the New Year.

We have carefully crafted a 12-minute special program showcasing scenes from Auckland (New Zealand), Sydney (Australia), and Hong Kong, among other locations.

In Paris, millions of people gathered on the Champs-Élysées to celebrate the 2024 Olympics-themed party. The fireworks display in the city center drew in a massive crowd, with the organizers describing it as the largest fireworks display in European history.

On Copacabana Beach in Rio de Janeiro, millions of people gathered to celebrate the New Year, making it the world's largest New Year's celebration, attracting 2.2 billion viewers.

0.text:
Terence Crawford won his fourth world title at different weights by beating Israil Madrimov to claim the WBA light-middleweight crown in Los Angeles. The 36-year-old American won by unanimous decision at the BMO Stadium to extend his unbeaten record to 41 fights. A former lightweight world champion who was also undisputed champion at light-welterweight and welterweight, Crawford triumphed 116-112, 115-113 and 115-113 on the judges' scorecards. Defeat was the first of 29-year-old Uzbek Madrimov's 11-bout career.

'Israil was a tough competitor,' said Crawford, who had not been taken to 12 rounds since 2016. 'He's real strong. He's durable. He took a lot of good shots. He got me to round 12. 'He had fast speed, a good rhythm upstairs. He was very disciplined and he fought a good fight. 'I was being patient. I didn't want to rush in with anything. That's how I got caught a couple times - I tried to eat too soon.' Crawford's win opened up the possibility of a fight with Mexico's super-middleweight champion Canelo Alvarez. 'If the money is right, we've got to fight,' said Crawford.
• None Notifications, social media and more with BBC Sport

Terence Crawford won the WBA light-middleweight championship at the BMO Stadium in Los Angeles, defeating Israil Madrimov by unanimous decision, becoming his fourth world title in a different weight class. The 36-year-old American boxer ended his 41-fight unbeaten streak with the victory. Crawford, previously a world champion in the lightweight division and undisputed super lightweight and middleweight champion, had the judges' scorecards of 116-112, 115-113 and 115-113.

Madrimov, 29, suffered his first loss since 11 wins. 

'Irshal is a great opponent,' Crawford said. 'He's strong, resilient. He took a lot of good shots. He took me to the 12th round. He's got quickness, good rhythm, his first round was great. He's disciplined, he fought a great fight. I was patient. I didn't want to catch him with a big shot. So I got caught a few times – I tried to eat too much.'

Crawford's victory opens the door for a possible bout with Mexican middleweight champion Canelo Alvarez. 'If the money is right, we'll fight,' Crawford said.

He is a retired American boxer with a professional record of 41 wins and 0 losses, with all victories by KO. The fight results show Crawford winning the middleweight, heavyweight, and heavyweight fights with scores of 116-112, 115-113, and 115-113 respectively.

Prior to the fight between Crawford and Madrid, 29-year-old Madrid had won 11 consecutive fights. Crawford highly praised Madrid, calling him 'a very tough opponent. He's strong, resilient, and can withstand a lot of punishment. He can take a hit. He has good rhythm and timing. He showed a lot of power in the first round. He's accurate, skilled in boxing, and very professional.'

Crawford said, 'I'm very patient; I don't want to get knocked out, so I've endured a lot of pain and hardship.' He also mentioned that if the conditions are right, he would like to fight Mexican middleweight champion Carlos Alvarez. Crawford said, 'If the conditions are right, we'll fight.'

80.text:

This was his fourth championship win, and he won multiple championships throughout his career, achieving success in various weight classes. His career record is 41-0, with all his wins being by knockout. The fight results showed that Crawford defeated Madridejos with scores of 116-112, 115-113, and 115-113 in middleweight, heavyweight, and heavyweight bouts.

Before fighting Crawford, 29-year-old Madridejos had won 11 consecutive fights. Crawford highly praised Madridejos, saying: 'He is a very cunning opponent. He is strong, resilient, and can withstand a lot of damage. He can withstand a punch. He has good rhythm and timing. He showed his power in the first round. He is accurate and professional.'

Crawford said: 'I am very patient, and I do not want to be knocked out, so I endured a lot of pain and difficulty.' He also mentioned that if conditions permit, he wants to fight Mexican middleweight champion Carlos Alvarez, saying: 'If the conditions allow, we will fight.'

He defeated Israeli boxer Madrimov at the Crypto.com Arena (formerly known as the BMO Arena) in Los Angeles, California, to win the world heavyweight championship. This was his fourth world title fight, and he has won multiple championships and victories in different weight classes. His career record is 41 wins and 0 losses, with all victories by knockout. The scores were 116-112, 115-113, and 115-113. Crawford has been a champion in the middleweight, heavyweight, and super heavyweight divisions.

Prior to his fight against Madrimov, Madrimov had won 11 consecutive matches, at just 29 years old. Crawford highly praised Madrimov, calling him 'a very cunning opponent. He's strong, resilient, and can take a lot of punishment. He can take a lot of punches. He's got good rhythm and timing. He showed his power in the first round. He's very accurate and professional.'

Crawford said, 'I'm very patient, I don't want to get knocked out, so I took a lot of pain and hardship.' He also mentioned that if the conditions allow, he would like to fight Mexican middleweight champion Carlos Alvarez, saying, 'If the conditions allow, we will fight.'

0.text:
A dust devil has been filmed dancing across a car park outside a cafe on an industrial park.

The phenomenon was filmed at KJ's Cafe in Marchwood, Hampshire, by Martin Somes on Thursday.

According to the Met Office, a dust devil is 'an upward spiralling dust filled vortex of air that may vary in height from a few feet to over 1,000'.

'They mainly occur in desert and semi-arid areas, where the ground is dry and high surface temperatures produce strong updrafts,' it added.

Although they resemble tornadoes, dust devils are not as powerful, but as they travel across the ground they can also carry other loose debris such as hay.

The Met Office describes a dust devil as a 'spinning column of air that can rise from a few feet to 1,000 feet, filled with dust'.

They typically occur in deserts and semi-arid regions, where the ground is dry and the surface temperature is high, generating powerful updrafts, the Met Office adds.

Although they may look like tornadoes, dust devils are not as powerful, but they can still pick up loose objects such as dry grass as they move across the ground.

British photographer Martin Summers captured these sandstorm photos in March.

The sandstorm occurred in Marchwood, Hampshire, England, where photographer Martin Summers was taking pictures at the time.

According to the Met Office, a sandstorm is a column of rotating air in the atmosphere, typically ranging in height from a few feet to several thousand feet.

The Met Office notes that sandstorms usually occur in desert and semi-arid regions where the ground is dry, the surface temperature is high, and the wind speed is strong – all of which contribute to the formation of sandstorms.

Although sandstorms may appear like whirlwinds, their actual movement speed is very slow, and their wind speed is far lower than that of whirlwinds, yet they can still lift dry grass and lightweight objects.

Police said the woman remains in custody

A woman has been arrested on suspicion of child neglect after three young siblings went missing.

Gloucestershire Police confirmed the three-year-old boy and the girls - aged five and eight - had now been found and were safe.

The children, who are from Cheltenham, were reported missing on Friday.

The force said the woman arrested in connection with the incident remained in police custody and thanked everyone who had helped find the children.

In a statement, a police spokesperson said 'Officers would like to thank everyone who shared our earlier appeal or submitted information on the children's whereabouts.'

The BBC is not responsible for the content of external sites.

0.text:
George Galloway was not at the count in Rochdale

Veteran left-winger George Galloway has lost the Rochdale seat he won only four months ago in a stunning by-election victory. The Workers Party of Britain founder did not attend the count at Rochdale Leisure Centre to hear the general election result. Reform UK's Michael Howard came third, with 6,773 votes.

It was a huge turnaround from Mr Galloway's landslide by-election victory, when he tapped into anger about Labour's stance on the conflict in Gaza to win by more than 6,000 votes. His campaign in February was hugely boosted by Labour's decision to withdraw support for its candidate, Azhar Ali, over remarks widely alleged to be antisemitic. After his victory earlier this year, Mr Galloway said: 'Keir Starmer and Rishi Sunak are two cheeks of the same backside and they both got well and truly spanked.' Mr Galloway was a Labour MP until 2003, before sitting in the Commons as an independent and Respect Party MP for three constituencies between 2003 and 2015.

What questions do you have for the new government?

2.text:
George Galloway, the founder of the British Workers' Party, failed to attend the vote-counting procedure held at the Rochdale Leisure Centre.

The founder of the British Workers' Party lost the seat in Rochdale in the stunning by-election victories in the first four months. Michael Howard of the Reform Party ranked third with 6,773 votes.

This is the critical moment of George Galloway's by-election victory, in which he won the election with a difference of more than 6,000 votes. He gained a lot of support in the election in February this year because the Labour Party decided to withdraw its candidate Azhar Ali's support, who had previously made some comments widely criticized as anti-Semitic. Earlier this year, George Galloway said, 'Kier Starmer and Rishi Sunak are two faces of the same coin, both got a good slap.' George Galloway was a Labour MP until 2003, and then participated in parliamentary work from 2003 to 2015 as an independent MP and then as an MP for the Respect Party.

George Galloway had almost never lost a seat, as his previous election victories had a lead of over 6,000 votes. George Galloway received a lot of support in the February election because the Labour Party withdrew the candidate Azhar Ali, who was widely criticized for his anti-Semitic remarks. Earlier this year, George Galloway said: 'Asad and Richard Seymour are double agents, they are harmful people.' George Galloway served as a Labour Party MP in 2003, and as an independent MP from 2003 to 2015. After losing his seat, he became a Respect Party MP.

An east London council is urging residents to dispose of hazardous waste properly after an empty gas bottle thrown in a household bin exploded in a refuse lorry, injuring a worker.

Footage captured in August, now released by Newham Council, shows the worker pressing a button on the side of a lorry before an explosion inside the truck blows a hole through the container.

The man can be seen bending over and running away following the blast, and the council said he had been 'rushed to the hospital with dizziness and hearing issues'.

Sarah Ruiz, Newham Council's statutory deputy mayor, said: 'We are grateful that our staff member is now recovering, but this incident could have been much worse.

'I urge everyone to be proactive and responsible, by taking these dangerous items to appropriate recycling locations.'

A young urban ecologist has been making an impact on social media by creating videos to raise awareness about the animals that live in London.

Akash Barua, 24, from Peckham in south-east London, started to develop his love for nature when visiting family in Scotland and from there started to look at wildlife in the capital.

He has got a graduate ecologist position carrying out bat surveys, which usually means working at night, but in his free time he makes social media videos, including an Instagram series called 'Wild Endz' which has looked at the beavers in Ealing and the sparrows and parakeets of Peckham.

Follow BBC London on Facebook, external, Twitter, external and Instagram, external. Send your story ideas to hellobbclondon@bbc.co.uk, external.

Preston North End forward Milutin Osmajic has been charged by the Football Association with violent conduct after allegedly biting Blackburn Rovers defender Owen Beck.

Beck, who is on loan from Liverpool, was sent off in the closing stages of Sunday's goalless Lancashire derby for kicking out at Preston's Duane Holmes.

A melee followed, with Beck, 22, furiously protesting to referee Matthew Donohue that he had been bitten by Osmajic, who received a yellow card.

Television replays appeared to show 25-year-old Osmajic had bitten Beck on his upper back.

Osmajic has until Monday, 30 September to provide a response, the FA said., external

Luis Suarez, then of Liverpool, received a 10-match ban in 2013 for biting Chelsea's Branislav Ivanovic.

Blackburn manager John Eustace told BBC Radio Lancashire: 'Owen's got a big bite mark on the back of his neck and it's a shame the referee didn't see that.'

2.text:
Preston's Milutin Osmajic is facing a charge from the Football Association, alleging that he bit Blackpool defender Owen Beck.

Beck, on loan from Liverpool, was sent off in Sunday's Lancashire derby, and in the second half, he kicked Preston's Duane Holmes.

Chaos erupted on the pitch as 22-year-old Beck anxiously complained to referee Matthew Donohue, claiming that he had been bitten by Osmajic, resulting in Osmajic being given a yellow card.

The television footage appeared to show 25-year-old Osmajic biting Beck on the upper back.

Osmajic will have the opportunity to respond to the charge by September 30, the Football Association said.

In 2013, Liverpool's Luis Suarez was banned for 10 matches for biting Chelsea's Branislav Ivanovic.

Blackpool manager John Eustace told BBC Lancashire: 'There's a big bite mark on Owen's neck, unfortunately the referee didn't see it.'

A witness examination can often play out like a game of chess: early moves will eventually set up a bigger play later.

Prosecutor Joshua Steinglass started off today by asking David Pecker about the times he’d personally witnessed Trump running his business.

Steinglass asked Pecker to describe Trump as a businessman. “Very knowledgeable, very detail oriented, almost a micro-manager,” Pecker replied.

And what was his approach to money like? “Frugal”, Pecker replies.

While this might seem flattering, prosecutors are likely trying to establish that Trump ran his business meticulously and was aware of how the Trump Organization spent his money.

Steinglass also asks if he ever saw Trump signing cheques, and if they were ever attached to invoices with staples or other means.

Pecker replied that he had watched Trump reviewing invoices and signing cheques, and recalled the corresponding items were often stapled together.

That detail might help prosecutors argue their claim that Trump in fact knew about the allegedly fraudulent way Michael Cohen was repaid for fronting the hush-money payment to Stormy Daniels.

On Monday, Trump’s lawyer asserted that the former president would not have had knowledge of that accounting process.

2.text:
During the questioning process of the witness, a chessboard-like situation often emerges: early actions ultimately lay the foundation for a larger future plan.

Prosecutor Joshua Steinglass began questioning David Peckler today about what he personally witnessed of Trump's actions in his business dealings.

Steinglass asked Peckler to describe how Trump portrayed himself as a businessman. Peckler replied, 'Very familiar with the market, very detail-oriented, almost a micro-manager.'

How did he view money? 'Frugal,' Peckler replied.

Although this sounds like praise, the prosecutor is likely trying to establish that Trump had a detailed understanding of his company's expenditures and knew how Trump Organization spent his money.

Steinglass also asked if he had ever seen Trump sign documents, and if so, whether these signatures were attached to invoices or handled in some other way.

Peckler replied that he had witnessed Trump reviewing invoices and signing them, and remembered that related projects were usually held together with clips.

This detail may help the prosecutor argue that Trump actually knew about the allegedly fraudulent accounting methods, including the anonymous payments made by Michael Cohen to Stormy Daniels.

On Monday, Trump's lawyers claimed that the former president was not aware of the accounting methods.

The BBC's Jessica Parker is at the scene, where a huge plume of smoke can be seen coming from a timber yard.

Homes and properties - including a school - in nearby towns are on fire as the wildfires continued overnight.

Aircraft working to extinguish the flames were forced to land when the sun set, making it a ground operation overnight. Residents have complained of a lack of fire trucks and firefighters, and the Greek authorities have accepted offers of international assistance.

Police dashcam footage has been released showing the moment a dangerous driver led officers on a high-speed chase.

Billy Ronchi, 22, was spotted driving 'erratically' and was pulled over by police in Cockington Road, Bilborough, Nottingham.

But when officers exited their car, Ronchi sped away, reaching speeds of about 70mph (112km/h) along residential streets, Nottinghamshire Police said.

Ronchi, of Baker Street, Derby, also passed through red lights and narrowly avoided crashing into a lorry.

The chase, which happened on 18 January, ended when Ronchi lost control of the car and crashed into a safety barrier.

He admitted dangerous driving, driving while disqualified and driving without a licence or insurance.

At Nottingham Crown Court, Ronchi was given a 16-month sentence, suspended for two years. He was also disqualified from driving for three years.

The force said Ronchi 'demonstrated a complete disregard for the safety of other road users when he sped through a built-up residential area in such a reckless manner'.

Pioneering jockey Rachael Blackmore faces a spell on the sidelines after injuring her neck in a fall.

Blackmore, the first female rider to win the Grand National, was injured at Downpatrick on Friday.

'Rachael Blackmore has sustained a neck injury and will not ride in the coming weeks, while she undergoes rehabilitation for her injury,' said Irish Horseracing Regulatory Board spokesman Niall Cronin.

An exact diagnosis or timeframe for her return has not been given.

The 35-year-old was injured when parting company with her mount Hand Over Fist, trained by Denis Howard, in a handicap chase.

Blackmore was voted BBC Sports Personality's World Sport Star of the Year for 2021 after winning the National at Aintree on Minella Times.

She was also the first woman to be leading jockey at the Cheltenham Festival, where she won the Gold Cup the following year on A Plus Tard.

Blackmore had been tied at the top of of the Irish jump jockeys' championship before her injury, with 23 winners alongside Keith Donoghue and Sam Ewing.

Transport for London, which is based at Palestra House in Southwark, said there was no evidence customer data had been compromised

Transport for London's (TfL) computer systems have been targeted in an ongoing cyber attack. It said there was no evidence customer data had been compromised and there was currently no impact on TfL services. Insiders have told BBC London they have been asked to work at home if possible, and that it is the transport provider's backroom systems at the corporate headquarters that are mainly affected. TfL’s chief technology officer Shashi Verma said: “We have introduced a number of measures to our internal systems to deal with an ongoing cyber security incident.'

He added: 'The security of our systems and customer data is very important to us and we will continue to assess the situation throughout and after the incident. 'Although we’ll need to complete our full assessment, at present there is currently no evidence that any customer data has been compromised. 'There is currently no impact to TfL services and we are working closely with the National Crime Agency and the National Cyber Security Centre to respond to the incident.”

Transport for London's computer systems are currently under a series of cyber attacks. The organization claims that there is currently no evidence to suggest that customer data has been stolen, and Transport for London's services are currently operating normally. According to a source at BBC London, the organization has asked employees to work from home as much as possible, with the main impact being on the organization's headquarters logistics system. Transport for London's Chief Technology Officer Shashi Verma said: 'We have taken some measures to reduce the impact of this cyber security incident on our internal systems.'

He added: 'We are very concerned about the safety of our systems and customer data. The development and outcome of this incident will continue to be assessed.'

Despite a thorough assessment, there is currently no evidence to suggest that customer data has been stolen. The organization claims: 'Currently, Transport for London's services are operating normally.' The organization is working closely with the Metropolitan Police and the National Cyber Security Centre to handle the incident.

Transport for London is working closely with the Metropolitan Police and the National Cyber Security Centre to handle the incident.

The previous owner said he had 'treasured' the goat all his life

A pottery goat made by King Charles has sold for £8,500. The small ceramic animal, which had been treasured for 55 years by Canadian Raymond Patten, was auctioned in Staffordshire on Tuesday. It was given to him on his 21st birthday by a great aunt who worked as a cook at Cambridge University. 'I believe she knew the future King on a personal basis. I have treasured the goat all my life,' Mr Patten said.

Mr Patten said his aunt 'told me Prince Charles had made it'. He added: 'She was proud of the fact he attended Cambridge University in the late 1960s when she worked as a cook for the president of Queens' College.' Charles Hanson, of Hansons Auctioneers, added: 'Raymond decided to part with the goat due to its historical significance. 'He is in his retirement years and wanted to find it a new home where it would be treasured for decades to come.' Follow BBC Stoke & Staffordshire on Facebook, external, X, external and Instagram, external. Send your story ideas to: newsonline.westmidlands@bbc.co.uk, external

A disabled woman says when the lift in her block breaks, she is often forced to sleep under the stairwell downstairs.

Joanne Scott lives in the Silwood Estate in Rotherhithe, south-east London, and says the lifts have broken down 67 times in the past year.

The housing association L&Q disputes the number of times the lift has broken down and how long it has been out of action during that time.

David Lewis, executive group director – property services at L&Q, added that the firm was 'very sorry for the problems that Ms Scott and the residents have experienced with the lift and recognise this has taken us too long to put right.

'All electrical and mechanical lift components are being replaced to ensure that it meets the highest standards and provides a long-term reliable service - our aim is to have this work completed by the end of this year.'

Follow BBC London on Facebook, external, Twitter, external and Instagram, external. Send your story ideas to hellobbclondon@bbc.co.uk, external.

A disabled woman said she often has to sleep on the stairs in her apartment building because the elevator breaks down so frequently.

Joan Scott, who lives in Lewisham, south-east London, said the lift had broken down 67 times in the past year.

Lewisham and Southwark's housing association, L&Q, disputed the frequency of lift breakdowns and the time it takes to repair them.

David Lewis, the chief executive of L&Q, said the company was deeply sorry for the difficulties faced by Joan Scott and other residents due to the lift issues and acknowledged that it had taken too long to resolve the problems.

He added: 'We will replace the electrical and mechanical components of the lifts comprehensively to ensure they meet the highest standards and provide long-term reliable service – our goal is to complete this work by the end of the year.'

Police have released dashcam footage of the moment a car collided with an oncoming vehicle.

The incident happened on 1 January 2023 in Peterborough.

Djiferson Monteiro, 35 of Deer Park Way, Thorney, pleaded guilty failing provide a specimen of blood for analysis, dangerous driving and driving without insurance.

He was sentenced at Cambridge Crown Court to eight months in prison, suspended for 18 months and disqualified from driving for two years, when he will be required to retake a test.

He must also complete a 20-day rehabilitation activity requirement and undertake 120 hours of unpaid work.

This article contains details of poor mental health and suicide. If you have been affected by any of the issues raised, BBC Action Line can provide contacts to find help.

'I've got some proper Halloween scars on this one.'

MMA fighter Paddy 'The Baddy' Pimblett points to the marks left by three operations on his foot. He's had another three on his hands.

'My body is falling apart at 29 - but I've been fighting since I was 15,' he says.

'I just get on with it.'

The Next Generation Gym is where he gets on with it.

Pimblett and Molly 'Meatball' McCann, 34, are the two highest-profile members of a tight-knit MMA fighting community at the renowned Liverpool gym.

It is where both are preparing for fights in Manchester later this month; contests which could be significant to their careers after 18 months of turbulence, headlines and life changes.

They are part of a wider, longer-term project though.

Their training is led by head coaches Paul Rimmer and Ellis Hampson, who joined forces 20 years ago to build an MMA community and a lasting legacy for Liverpool.

0.text:
For now, there’s a sigh of relief, a pause.

Israel’s limited strike, not officially acknowledged, has given space to Tehran. In this grey area, its leaders are casting it as a slap so weak it’s not even clear who did it. They don’t lose face after days of declarations vowing that even the tiniest Israeli invasion would provoke an immediate and harsh response.

Many had predicted Israel would wait until after Passover to retaliate. It appears to have decided it needed to hit sooner, to send a clear signal, just before the holiday starts. It may still strike again, in a different place, with different force, when this period ends.

But as my colleague Jeremy Bowen writes, this crisis really illustrates how badly Iran and Israel understand each other.

This may have been just a warning salvo into the beating heart of Iran, the province of Isfahan with its stunning Islamic architecture but also a nuclear facility, a major air base, the industrial heartland including drone and ballistic missile factories.

This round may be over, for now, but the seething hostility between two regional rivals is not.

2.text:
Currently, people are enjoying a temporary respite, a brief pause.

Israel's limited strikes, although not officially acknowledged, have left Gaza some room to breathe. In this grey area, Gaza's leaders describe it as a weak strike, and even unclear who is behind it. They have been issuing statements over the past few days, vowing to respond immediately and severely to any Israeli incursion.

Many people predict that Israel will wait for a response before the new year. It appears to have made a decision, needing to send a clear signal before the holiday begins. It may still launch another attack, in another location, using different troops, by the time this period ends.

But my colleague Jeremy Bowen writes that this crisis has truly exposed the misconceptions between Iran and Israel.

This may be just a warning shot across the heart of Iran, Isfahan Province, known for its stunning Islamic architecture, and home to nuclear facilities, a large airbase, industrial hubs, including drone and ballistic missile factories.

This cycle has temporarily stopped, but the anger of the two opposing forces in the region has not yet dissipated.

Although there has been no official confirmation, Israel's limited airstrikes on the Gaza Strip have temporarily eased the tense situation. However, in this gray area, high-ranking officials refer to it as 'weak tea,' but the actual situation remains unclear. Recently, they issued a statement, promising to respond rapidly and severely regardless of the circumstances.

Many people predict that Israel will take further action before receiving a response. It seems they have decided to send a clear signal before the holidays begin. However, it is also possible that they will use different troops to launch another attack at different locations until this cycle ends.

However, my colleague Jeremy Bowen wrote that this crisis has truly exposed the communication breakdown between Iran and Israel.

This could be a warning signal targeting Iran's internal affairs – the Israelis know that the Isfahan Province in Iran is famous for its magnificent Islamic architecture, including nuclear facilities, massive airports, industrial centers, drone factories, and ballistic missile factories.

This cycle has been temporarily disrupted, but both sides are filled with anger, and the flames have not been extinguished yet.

0.text:
“Oh god! We’ve got a Labour government!” A delighted member of the Cabinet told me reality only finally hit them when driving through their constituency on Friday, more than a week after voters sent the Tories packing.

In the prime minister’s first seven days he’s been confronted with a deeply awkward situation abroad – President Joe Biden’s competence dominating the NATO summit.

At home the justice secretary has felt compelled to plan early prisoner releases (it’s unusual a politician would make a willing choice to do that), and doubts over the survival of the steel plant in Port Talbot linger.

In other words, Labour is already grappling with the tasks government requires them to do – not the options they would choose.

But on Wednesday their own plans will take centre stage, with all the fuss and fanfare Westminster can summon – the attendance of the King, the giant golden throne (yes, really!), the trumpets, the frills and flounces.

The first ‘King’s Speech’ will list the law the government hopes to pass in its first year of what Labour already hopes will be a decade in charge.

2.text:
A miracle has happened! We now have a Labour government! A cabinet member told me that it was only last Friday that they came to their senses, when they were canvassing - a whole week after the voters had already sent the Conservatives packing.

In his first seven days in office, the prime minister faced a rather awkward diplomatic situation - Biden's performance at the NATO summit dominated the headlines.

Domestically, the home secretary felt the urgent need to release prisoners (for a politician, this is a rare move), while the fate of the Port Talbot steelworks also sparked controversy.

In other words, Labour is now doing what needs to be done - rather than what they wanted to do.

But on Wednesday, Labour will put on its own show, Westminster will be decked out in all its finery and ritual - the king's presence, the massive golden throne (yes!), trumpets, elegant attire, and all the trimmings.

The first 'royal speech' will outline the government's bills it hopes to pass in the first year, which is also the first year Labour has been in power in a decade.

Miracle finally happened! We finally have a Labour government! On Friday morning, cabinet members told me that their members have started knocking on doors in my constituency, explaining to voters that they switched to Labour a week ago.

The Prime Minister is facing diplomatic embarrassment – Joe Biden's performance at the NATO summit has caused a huge reaction.

Domestically, the Home Secretary thinks that the King's pardon should be issued (a rare action in the political circle), while the fate of the Port Talbot steelworks has become a contentious issue.

In fact, the Labour Party is now doing what needs to be done, rather than what they want to do.

However, on Wednesday, the Labour Party will host its own celebration, Westminster will become Buckingham Palace – the King's arrival, a massive golden throne (yes!), 21-gun salute, exquisite attire, all the details will be replicated.

The government will explain the laws they hope to pass in the first year through the Prime Minister's speech, aimed at achieving the targets that Labour failed to achieve over the past decade.
